questions.text: A 42-year-old lady complains of nocturnal pain over the thumb, index finger and middle finger. Which of the following tests is required to reach a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lady is suffering from carpal tunnel syndrome.

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome(tardive median palsy) is the result of compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel as it passes beneath the flexor retinaculum.
  • Clinical findings:
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome is most common in the fourth to sixth decades of life and occurs more often in women than in men.
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome consists predominantly of tingling and numbness in the typical median nerve distribution in the radial three and a half digits (thumb, index, long and radial side of ring).
    • Tingling is more prominent during sleep. Frequently causes the patient to awaken several hours after falling asleep with burning and numbness in the hand, which is relieved by exercise.
    • Pain, described as deep, aching or throbbing, occurs diffusely in the hand and radiates up the forearm.
  • Tests for carpal tunnel syndrome are:
    • Percussion test(Tinel sign):Tapping over the median nerve at the mid-axis of the wrist elicits electric-shock-like discomfort at the site of the tap with paresthesias that radiate distally into the median nerve distribution(positive Tinel sign).
    • Phalen test(or Phalen manoeuvre):The Phalen manoeuvre provokes median nerve compression by active hyperflexion of the wrist; this test is considered positive if paresthesias in a median nerve distribution develop within 60 seconds.
    • Tourniquet test:The development of numbness and tingling in the fingers in the median nerve distribution after an inflated blood pressure cuff is placed on the upper arm suggests carpal tunnel syndrome.
    • Durkan compression test:Compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomiser bulb attached to a manometer. Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome typically experience symptoms of numbness, pain, or paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cozen's test (Option A): Elicits pain in the lateral epicondyle, used for diagnosing tennis elbow.

Finkelstein test (Option B): Used to diagnose De Quervain's tenosynovitis, not related to the median nerve.

Eichhoff test (Option D): Also used in De Quervain's tenosynovitis by passive ulnar deviation-irrelevant to carpal tunnel syndrome.

Key Takeaway: Phalen's test is a classic diagnostic manoeuvre for carpal tunnel syndrome, reproducing symptoms via wrist flexion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with clawing of the ring and little fingers following a deep cut near the medial aspect of the wrist. He has difficulty gripping objects. Which of the following splints would be most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has classic features of ulnar nerve palsy, including claw hand deformity due to paralysis of the medial two lumbrical and interossei.

  • The knuckle-bender splint keeps the MCP joints in flexion, thereby preventing clawing of the ulnar two digits.
  • It compensates for the loss of lumbrical function and helps maintain a functional grip.
  • Most effective in low ulnar nerve injuries affecting the hand.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cock-up splint (Option A): Used for radial nerve palsy, supports wrist and finger extensors.

Opponents splint (Option C): Used for median nerve palsy, helps in thumb opposition.

Foot-drop splint (Option D): Used for common peroneal nerve palsy, aids in dorsiflexion during gait.

Key Takeaway:

Knuckle-bender splint is the splint of choice for correcting claw-hand deformity seen in ulnar nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently underwent a left mastectomy and axillary dissection for breast cancer now presents to her physician with a chief complaint that she feels like her shoulder blade sticks out sometimes. She denies any pain. This patient's injured nerve originates at which spinal levels?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has developed winging of the scapula due to injury to the long thoracic nerve, a known complication of axillary dissection in breast surgery.

  • The long thoracic nerve originates from the C5, C6, and C7 roots of the brachial plexus and supplies the serratus anterior muscle, which stabilises the scapula against the thoracic wall.
  • Classic clinical test: Ask the patient to push against a wall. If the medial border of the scapula lifts off, it confirms winging.
  • Painless winging, as seen here, is typical in iatrogenic long thoracic nerve palsy, commonly due to mastectomy, first rib resection, or brachial neuritis.
  • Most cases of axonotmesis involving this nerve resolve spontaneously over 12–18 months. Persistent cases may require muscle transfer or scapulothoracic fusion.

Key Takeaway:

Winging of the scapula post-axillary surgery indicates long thoracic nerve injury, which arises from C5, C6, and C7 spinal roots.

questions.text: A patient is asked to hold a sheet of paper tightly between their thumb and index finger. On attempting to resist the pull of the examiner, the patient compensates by flexing the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, as shown in the image. Which nerve is primarily being assessed with this test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test shown is Froment's sign, a bedside clinical sign used to assess ulnar nerve integrity, particularly in relation to the adductor pollicis muscle.

  • The patient is instructed to grip a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger.
  • If the ulnar nerve is compromised, the adductor pollicis (ulnar-innervated) is weak.
  • To compensate, the patient uses flexor pollicis longus (median nerve), causing flexion of the thumb's interphalangeal joint-a positive Froment's sign.
  • This indicates a low ulnar nerve palsy, commonly seen in Guyon's canal syndrome or post-traumatic lesions.
  • For the ulnar nerve, remember:
    • Adductor pollicus
    • Book test - for adductor pollicis
    • Card test - to checkthe palmar interossei
    • Egawa test - to check the dorsal interossei
    • Froment sign.

Explanation of Other Options:

Median nerve (Option A): Involved in opposition and flexion of the thumb, not adduction-does not explain the test shown.

Radial nerve (Option B): Innervates extensors of the wrist and fingers-not related to this test.

Anterior interosseous nerve (Option D): A branch of the median nerve; that affects flexor pollicis longus and FDP to index finger, but has no sensory component-irrelevant to this test.

Key Takeaway:

Froment's sign is a clinical indicator of ulnar nerve palsy, caused by weakness of the adductor pollicis muscle.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was involved in a motorcycle crash and sustained the injury shown in Figure A. In the trauma bay, it was noted that the patient could not extend his wrist. What artery runs with his injured nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has a Holstein-Lewis fracture, a distal third humeral shaft fracture commonly associated with radial nerve palsy.

  • The radial nerve and profunda brachii artery travel together in the spiral groove of the humerus.
  • This anatomical relationship places both the nerve and artery at risk during distal humeral shaft fractures.
  • Radial nerve palsy typically presents as:
    • Wrist drop (loss of wrist extension)
    • Inability to extend fingers and thumb
    • Weak grip
  • Fortunately, 80-90% of radial nerve injuries in this context are neuropraxia and recover spontaneously with conservative management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior circumflex humeral artery (Option B): Travels with the axillary nerve around the surgical neck of the humerus-not involved in shaft fractures.

Scapular circumflex artery (Option C): Found in the triangular space, does not travel with any major nerve.

Brachial artery (Option D): Lies anterior and medial in the arm, closely related to the median and ulnar nerves, not the radial nerve.

Key Takeaway:

Radial nerve injury with wrist drop following a distal humeral fracture suggests the involvement of the profunda brachii artery, which accompanies the radial nerve in the spiral groove.

choices.text: Pain sensation to the radial portion of the dorsum of the hand
Temperature sensation to the radial portion of the dorsum of the hand
Sensation of light touch to the radial portion of the dorsum of the hand

questions.text: A 36-year-old male injured his right arm after a fall. His injury radiograph is shown in Figure A. On physical examination, he was found to have a nerve injury. Which function is the last to return?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In peripheral nerve injuries, functions are lost and recovered in a predictable order. Motor function is the first to be lost and the last to recover.

  • This patient has a Holstein-Lewis fracture, which is a spiral fracture of the distal third of the humerus commonly associated with radial nerve palsy.
  • The radial nerve is responsible for extension at the wrist and fingers, as well as sensory supply to the dorsum of the hand.
  • Recovery of nerve function occurs in reverse order of loss, i.e., pain and temperature recover first, followed by touch and proprioception, with motor function recovering last.

Recovery Sequence in Peripheral Nerve Injuries:

Explanation of Other Options:

Pain sensation (Option A): Recovers early as it is among the last to be lost.

Temperature sensation (Option B): Recovers before touch and motor.

Light touch (Option C): Returns before motor function.

Key Takeaway:

Motor function is the first to be lost and the last to return in peripheral nerve injuries-hence, wrist extension is the last to recover in radial nerve palsy.

questions.text: The figure shows a cross-sectional image of a nerve. Which of the following represents item D?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The peripheral nerve is a composite structure made of axons bundled into fascicles and surrounded by protective connective tissue layers.

  • Perineurium (label D) surrounds a fascicle (bundle of nerve fibres) and maintains the blood-nerve barrier.
  • It is composed of concentric layers of flattened cells and collagen, giving structural integrity to each fascicle.
  • It is crucial in protecting the nerve fibres from mechanical injury and maintaining the internal environment.

Key Takeaway:

The perineurium surrounds nerve fascicles and forms the protective barrier critical for peripheral nerve integrity.

choices.text: Abnormal Semmes-Weinstein testing in wrist-neutral position
Positive median nerve compression test(Durkan's sign)
Loss of small digit adduction(Wartenberg sign)

questions.text: All of the following are predictive findings for correctly diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thumb adduction is supplied by the ulnar nerve and is not affected in carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves the median nerve.

  • Carpal tunnel syndrome presents with sensory symptoms like burning, tingling, and numbness in the lateral 3½ digits, often worsening at night.
  • Motor weakness typically involves the abductor pollicis brevis (thumb abduction), not the adductor pollicis.
  • Thenar wasting and clumsiness with tasks such as buttoning are seen in advanced cases.
  • The condition is most common in middle-aged women, particularly in contexts like pregnancy, menopause, or hypothyroidism.
  • Provocative signs such as Tinel's sign, Phalen's test, and Durkan's test help in diagnosis. (Option C ruled out)
  • Sensory loss is confined to the median nerve territory, sparing the thenar eminence due to the palmar cutaneous branch arising proximally. (Option A ruled out)
  • Semmes-Weinstein testing assesses threshold touch perception and reveals abnormal results in wrist-neutral positions in cases of CTS. (Option B ruled out)
  • Electrodiagnostic studies confirm the slowing of median nerve conduction across the wrist.

Key Takeaway:

Thumb abduction is impaired in CTS due to median nerve involvement, while the ulnar nerve mediates thumb adduction and remains unaffected.

questions.text: Klumpke's paralysis results from injury to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Klumpke's paralysis is caused by injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus, predominantly affecting the C8 and T1 nerve roots.

  • It typically results from excessive arm abduction, such as when grasping something during a fall or in birth injuries like breech delivery.
  • The intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) and ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) are paralysed.
  • The hallmark deformity is a claw hand, due to the unopposed action of the long flexors and extensors of the fingers:
    • Hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints
    • Flexion at interphalangeal joints
  • There may also be cutaneous anaesthesia along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.
  • Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, enophthalmos) may be associated with T1 sympathetic involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

C5 C6 (Option A): Involves upper trunk injury (Erb's palsy), not Klumpke's.

Radial nerve injury (Option C): Affects extensors of the wrist/fingers, not related to intrinsic hand muscles.

C5, C6 and C7 injury (Option D): Corresponds to Erb-Duchenne or extended Erb's palsy, not lower trunk palsy.

Key Takeaway:

Klumpke's palsy involves the lower trunk (C8-T1), leading to claw hand and sometimes Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: What nerve injury is shown by the mechanism in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wrist drop after compression of the radial nerve in the spiral groove is characteristic of Saturday night palsy.

  • The radial nerve may be compressed in the spiral groove of the humerus during prolonged pressure (e.g., sleeping on an arm/chair or crutch use).
  • This results in the inability to extend the wrist (wrist drop) and metacarpophalangeal joints, with preserved wrist extension by extensor carpi radialis longus (which arises proximal to the compression).
  • Commonly seen after alcohol intoxication or sedation, where the patient sleeps in an awkward posture.
  • Sensory loss is limited to a small area on the dorsum of the hand near the anatomical snuffbox.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve (Option A): Injury causes sensory loss over the radial 3½ digits and thumb abduction weakness; not associated with wrist drop.

Axillary nerve (Option B): Involved in shoulder abduction and deltoid innervation; not responsible for wrist extension.

Ulnar nerve (Option D): Injury leads to claw hand and sensory loss in medial 1½ digits; wrist extension remains intact.

Key Takeaway:

Radial nerve compression in the spiral groove (Saturday night palsy) presents with classical wrist drop and minimal sensory loss.

questions.text: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve beneath the flexor retinaculum, commonly associated with conditions that cause fluid retention, connective tissue swelling, or increased volume within the carpal canal.

  • Common causes include:
    • Pregnancy - due to fluid retention and hormonal changes.
    • Hypothyroidism - results in mucopolysaccharide deposition and soft tissue swelling. (Option A ruled out)
    • Acromegaly - due to soft tissue overgrowth from excess growth hormone. (Option D ruled out)
    • Rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and amyloidosis are also recognised causes.

Key Takeaway:

Tuberculosis does not directly cause carpal tunnel syndrome, unlike endocrine or systemic conditions like hypothyroidism, pregnancy, or acromegaly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with weakness in hand grip. The image below shows the clinical finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical image shows classic features of ape thumb deformity, characterised by:

  • Flattening of the thenar eminence
  • Thumb lying in the same plane as the fingers
  • Loss of opposition due to median nerve palsy, particularly affecting opponents pollicis

Explanation of Other Options:

Ulnar claw hand (Option A): Involves clawing of the 4th and 5th digits with ulnar nerve palsy.

Wrist drop (Option B): Due to radial nerve palsy, with the inability to extend the wrist, thumb positioning is not characteristic.

Pointing index (Option D): Due to high median nerve palsy, this leads to the inability to flex the index finger.

Key Takeaway:

Ape thumb deformity is caused by median nerve injury, leading to loss of thumb opposition and flattening of the thenar eminence.

questions.text: Guyon's canal is the site of entrapment neuropathy for which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Guyon's canal is a fibro-osseous tunnel at the wrist through which the ulnar nerve passes. Compression of the ulnar nerve at this site leads to ulnar tunnel syndrome, classically seen in cyclists due to prolonged pressure at the wrist.

  • It causes sensory symptoms in the medial 1½ fingers and motor deficits such as weakness of finger abduction/adduction and thumb adduction.
  • The deformity includes clawing of the ring and little fingers, and positive Froment's sign due to adductor pollicis weakness.
  • Wasting of the hypothenar and interosseous muscles is typically observed.
  • Guyon's canal compression is a low lesion of the ulnar nerve.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve (Option B): Entrapped at the carpal tunnel, not in Guyon's canal.

Radial nerve (Option C): Typically compressed at the spiral groove or radial tunnel.

Axillary nerve (Option D): Injured in anterior shoulder dislocation; not a tunnel-related entrapment.

Key Takeaway:

Guyon's canal syndrome is a common entrapment neuropathy of the ulnar nerve at the wrist, presenting with clawing of the medial fingers, motor weakness, and sensory loss in the ulnar distribution.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm

questions.text: Cheiralgia paraesthetica is a compression neuropathy of which nerve
questions.solution:
Cheiralgia paresthetica is caused by compression of the superficial radial nerve, a purely sensory branch, resulting in pain and paresthesia on the radial side of the dorsum of the hand and thumb.

  • Wartenberg's syndrome is typically due to entrapment of the superficial branch of the radial nerve, often from tight wristbands, watches, or trauma.
  • No motor weakness is seen, distinguishing it from posterior interosseous nerve involvement.
  • It is analogous to meralgia paresthetica in the lower limb.

Common Entrapment Neuropathies:

Explanation of other options:

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option A): Causes motor weakness in finger/wrist extension but no sensory deficit, unlike cheiralgia paresthetica.

Sural nerve (Option C): Affects lateral foot/calf; unrelated to dorsal hand.

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (Option D): Involved in meralgia paresthetica-presents with thigh paresthesia, not hand.

Key Takeaway:

Cheiralgia paresthetica is a sensory neuropathy of the superficial radial nerve, presenting with dorsoradial hand paresthesias but no motor loss.

questions.text: A child sustains a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. On examination, there is extension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints (claw hand), with sensory loss along the medial aspect of the hand and forearm. Which root levels are most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a claw hand deformity and sensory loss along the medial aspect of the forearm and hand point to the involvement of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus, which arises from the C8-T1 nerve roots.

  • C8 and T1 roots contribute to the ulnar nerve and the medial cutaneous nerves of the arm and forearm.
  • Injury at this level causes paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles (leading to claw hand) and loss of sensation in the ulnar distribution.
  • Though median or radial nerve injury can occur in supracondylar fractures, the described pattern of muscle involvement and sensory loss fits a root-level diagnosis better.
  • This presentation is consistent with Klumpke's palsy, which involves C8-T1 root damage, often seen with lower brachial plexus injury.

Explanation of other options:

C5-C6 (Option A): Associated with Erb's palsy-weakness in shoulder abduction and elbow flexion, not claw hand.

C5-C7 (Option B): Involves upper and middle trunks, again not associated with intrinsic hand paralysis.

C6-C8 (Option D): Overlaps partially, but C8-T1 best explains the sensory and motor findings.

Key Takeaway:

Claw hand with sensory loss along the medial hand and forearm indicates C8-T1 root involvement.

questions.text: Motor march is seen in:
questions.solution:
Motor march refers to the sequential recovery of muscles from proximal to distal due to regenerating axons, a phenomenon characteristic of axonotmesis.

  • Axonotmesis involves disruption of axons with preservation of the endoneurial tubes, allowing for Wallerian degeneration followed by regeneration.
  • Recovery occurs at approximately 1-2 mm/day, with muscles nearest to the site of injury reinnervated first-this orderly progression is termed motor march.
  • Neurapraxia represents a temporary conduction block without axonal disruption; no degeneration or motor march is seen.
  • Neurotmesis includes both axonal and connective tissue disruption, with a poor prognosis unless surgically repaired.
  • Axonpraxia is not a recognised classification in the Seddon or Sunderland systems.

Key Takeaway: Motor march occurs in axonotmesis due to preserved endoneurium, allowing axonal regeneration.

questions.text: A patient is asked to hold a card between the extended fingers while the examiner tries to pull it away. The inability to hold the card suggests weakness in which nerve and muscle group?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inability to hold a card between fingers during the Card Test indicates weakness of the palmar interossei, which are responsible for finger adduction and are innervated by the ulnar nerve.

  • Palmar interossei (PAD): Adduct the fingers; tested by asking the patient to grip a card between adjacent fingers.
  • Card test: Assesses palmar interossei strength and, indirectly, ulnar nerve integrity.
  • Other related tests for ulnar nerve:
    • Egawa's test: Tests dorsal interossei (abduction) by moving the middle finger side-to-side with the palm resting on a flat surface.
    • Froment&'s sign: Assesses adductor pollicis by asking the patient to grip a card with thumb and index finger; flexion of IP joint of the thumb (due to FPL compensation) indicates ulnar nerve palsy.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option A): Innervates wrist and finger extensors, not interossei.

Median nerve (Option C): Supplies thenar muscles and lateral lumbricals; not involved in adduction.

Tibial nerve (Option D): Supplies posterior leg and foot muscles; unrelated to hand function.

Key Takeaway: The card test specifically evaluates palmar interossei supplied by the ulnar nerve, useful in diagnosing ulnar neuropathy.

questions.text: Identify the splint shown in the image
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aeroplane splint is a shoulder abduction orthosis primarily used following injuries to the intercostobrachial nerve or brachial plexus injuries to:

  • Prevent contractures
  • Promote proper nerve regeneration
  • Maintain optimal abduction and external rotation of the shoulder

The intercostobrachial nerve is commonly injured during axillary dissection or shoulder surgeries, leading to sensory deficits. The aeroplane splint maintains limb position to prevent stretching or further injury.

Other splints and their indications:

  • Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy (prevents claw hand deformity)
  • Dennis Brown splint - CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinovarus) management
  • Bohler-Brown splint - Immobilisation in femur fractures (neck to supracondylar)
  • Turnbuckle splint - Used in Volkmann's ischemic contracture to gradually stretch the contracted soft tissues

Key Takeaway:

An Aeroplane splint is classically used in intercostobrachial or brachial plexus nerve injuries to maintain optimal upper limb positioning.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man falls asleep in a drunken state with his arm draped over the back of a chair. He wakes up unable to extend his wrist and fingers. Examination shows wrist drop and intact sensation. What is the most likely classification of nerve injury in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a classic case of Saturday night palsy, caused by compression of the radial nerve against the humerus in the spiral groove.
  • This results in a reversible conduction block without axonal damage - termed neuropraxia.
  • Neuropraxia is the mildest form of nerve injury per Seddon's classification.
  • It is caused by segmental demyelination and usually recovers spontaneously in days to weeks.
  • Common causes: crutch palsy, tourniquet palsy, Saturday night palsy.

Explanation of other options:

Division of nerve sheath (Option A): Seen in higher-grade injuries like neurotmesis, not in neuropraxia.

Division of axons (Option B): Indicates axonotmesis or neurotmesis, not compatible with reversible conduction block.

Division of nerve fibres (Option C): Seen in neurotmesis where complete transection occurs.

Key Takeaway:

Neuropraxia is a transient and fully reversible conduction block, typically due to nerve compression without axonal disruption.

questions.text: A 34-year-old factory worker presents with numbness and tingling along the medial side of his hand, especially involving the little finger and medial half of the ring finger. On examination, there is a sensory loss in this distribution and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. Which dermatome is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's symptoms suggest ulnar nerve involvement, which supplies the C8 dermatome, responsible for sensation over the little finger and medial half of the ring finger.

  • C6 - Thumb
  • C7 - Middle finger
  • C8 - Little finger and medial border of hand
  • T1 - Medial forearm

Ulnar nerve injuries commonly manifest with sensory loss in the C8 distribution, as well as motor deficits like hypothenar wasting, loss of finger adduction/abduction (interossei), and claw hand deformity in chronic cases.

Explanation of other options:

C6 dermatome (Option A): Supplies the thumb and lateral forearm-affected in radial or median nerve issues.

C7 dermatome (Option B): Supplies the middle finger and is often involved in cervical disc disease.

T1 dermatome (Option D): Supplies the medial forearm, not the little finger.

Key Takeaway:

Sensory loss over the little finger corresponds to the C8 dermatome, typically affected in ulnar nerve lesions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with Hansen's disease presents with clumsiness while performing fine motor tasks like buttoning his shirt. Examination reveals wasting of the hypothenar eminence and ulnar claw hand. The clumsiness is most likely due to palsy of which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The interossei, supplied by the ulnar nerve, are crucial for fine motor control like finger abduction and adduction. Their loss causes impaired dexterity and clumsiness.

  • The ulnar nerve is termed the "musician's nerve" because of its control over fine hand movements.
  • In leprosy, ulnar nerve involvement is common due to superficial location, leading to interosseous muscle paralysis and claw hand.

Muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve:

  • Forearm: Flexor carpi ulnaris, the medial half of flexor digitorum profundus
  • Hand: Palmaris brevis, hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, medial 2 lumbricals, all interossei

Explanation of other options:

Extensor carpi ulnaris (Option A): Supplied by radial nerve, not involved in fine hand dexterity.

Abductor pollicis brevis (Option B): Supplied by the median nerve; involved in thumb abduction.

Opponens pollicis (Option C): Median nerve supply; responsible for thumb opposition.

Key Takeaway:

Clumsiness in ulnar nerve palsy is primarily due to interossei muscle paralysis, which affects fine motor control.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with numbness over the radial aspect of the forearm, thumb, and index finger. On examination, there is weakness in wrist extension due to involvement of the extensor carpi radialis longus. Which cervical nerve root is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

C6 radiculopathy presents with sensory loss over:

  • Radial side of the forearm
  • Thumb and index finger

It also affects motor power in muscles like:

  • Extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis, leading to weak wrist extension
  • Biceps (reflex may be diminished)

This distribution of both sensory and motor findings is classic for C6 root involvement.

Explanation of other options:

C8 (Option A): Affects ulnar side of hand/forearm, leads to weakness in finger flexors (FDP, FDS)

C5 (Option B): Affects deltoid and biceps, sensory loss over lateral arm, not forearm

C7 (Option D): Affects triceps and finger extensors; sensory loss over middle finger

Key Takeaway:

Radial forearm and thumb sensory loss with wrist extensor weakness point toward C6 nerve root injury.

choices.text: Loss of abduction at the shoulder joint
Loss of pronation at radioulnar joint
Loss of flexion at elbow joint

questions.text: A 19-year-old male fell off his motorcycle and landed on his shoulder. He presents with the characteristic "waiter's tip" posture of the upper limb. On examination, there is loss of abduction and lateral rotation at the shoulder and loss of flexion at the elbow. Which of the following findings is least likely in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erb's palsy results from injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5-C6), commonly following traction injuries like falls on the shoulder or difficult childbirth.

Muscles affected include:

  • Deltoid and supraspinatus (loss of shoulder abduction)(Option A ruled out)
  • Infraspinatus and teres minor (loss of lateral rotation)(Option B ruled out)
  • Biceps and brachialis (loss of elbow flexion)(Option D ruled out)
  • Supinator (weak supination, but not pronation)

Since the pronator teres and pronator quadratus are supplied by the median nerve (C6-C7), pronation is preserved.

  • Characteristic posture: Arm adducted, internally rotated, elbow extended, and forearm pronated
  • Sensory loss: Variable over the lateral aspect of the arm and forearm
  • Reflexes: Biceps and brachioradialis reflexes are absent

Key Takeaway:

In Erb's palsy (C5-C6 injury), shoulder abduction, lateral rotation, and elbow flexion are lost, but pronation is spared.

questions.text: A 22-year-old professional tennis player presents with lateral elbow pain that radiates down the forearm. The pain is described as shooting and worsens with wrist extension and forearm rotation. On examination, tenderness is noted over the lateral epicondyle. Repetitive overuse of which of the following muscles is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is classic for lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow), which is a degenerative tendinopathy rather than an inflammatory. The most commonly involved muscle is the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB).

  • Originates at the lateral epicondyle
  • Involved in repetitive wrist extension and forearm rotation
  • Common in both racquet sports and manual occupations
  • Pain elicited with resisted wrist extension with the elbow extended and the forearm pronated
  • Histology: Angiofibroblastic hyperplasia
  • Grip strength often diminishes with elbow is extended
  • Treatment:
    • Conservative: NSAIDs, counterforce bracing, occupational therapy
    • Injection therapy (PRP or corticosteroids) - mixed evidence
    • Surgery (ECRB debridement ± lateral epicondylectomy) in resistant cases

Explanation of other options:

Extensor carpi radialis (Option B): Vague term; likely refers to the group; ECRB is the specific muscle involved.

Extensor carpi ulnaris (Option C): Inserts on the ulnar side and is implicated in medial epicondylitis or ECU tendinitis.

Extensor carpi radialis longus (Option D): Involved in wrist extension but less commonly injured in lateral epicondylitis than ECRB.

Key Takeaway:

Lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) is most commonly due to overuse of the extensor carpi radialis brevis, not the longus.

questions.text: A patient develops a complete wrist drop following a midshaft fracture of the humerus. There is the inability to extend the wrist and fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints. Sensory loss is noted over the anatomical snuffbox. Which of the following best describes the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wrist drop is most classically seen with high radial nerve palsy, commonly due to injury in the radial groove of the humerus.

  • High radial palsy involves radial extensors of the wrist and finger extensors.
  • Wrist drop occurs due to loss of extension at the wrist and MCP joints.
  • The triceps may be spared if the lesion is distal to its innervation.
  • Sensory loss is limited to the dorsum around the anatomical snuffbox.
  • Very high lesions (e.g., from axillary trauma or crutch palsy) may also involve the triceps and present with absent triceps reflex.
  • Low lesions (e.g., at the elbow or PIN entrapment) typically spare wrist extensors and involve only digital extension.
  • Posterior interosseous nerve palsy causes finger and thumb drop without wrist drop.

Explanation of other options:

Low radial nerve palsy (Option A): Wrist extension usually preserved; finger drop may occur, not wrist drop.

Posterior interosseous nerve palsy (Option B): Causes finger and thumb drop; wrist extension via ECRL remains.

Avulsion of triceps tendon (Option D): Leads to loss of elbow extension, not wrist drop.

Key Takeaway:

Wrist drop is most characteristic of high radial nerve palsy, often following a midshaft humerus fracture.

questions.text: This test is done to identify which nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is the Pen Test, performed to evaluate abductor pollicis brevis, a thenar muscle innervated by the median nerve.

  • The patient places the hand palm up on a flat surface.
  • A pen is held vertically above the thumb.
  • The patient is asked to lift the thumb straight up to touch the pen - this tests abduction.

Thenar Muscles Supplied by Median Nerve:

  • Abductor pollicis brevis → Pen test target muscle
  • Opponens pollicis → Assists in thumb opposition (not tested here)
  • Flexor pollicis brevis (superficial head)

Not Supplied by Median Nerve:

  • Adductor pollicis → Supplied by ulnar nerve

This test helps localize median nerve palsy at the wrist (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome) and assess thenar muscle integrity.

Explanation of other options:

Ulnar nerve (Option B): Supplies adductor pollicis and interossei; not tested by thumb abduction.

Posterior interosseous nerve (Option C): Motor branch of radial nerve; controls finger/wrist extensors, not thenar muscles.

Radial nerve (Option D): No motor supply to thenar muscles; injury leads to wrist drop, not affected in a pen test.

Key Takeaway:

The Pen Test assesses median nerve function via abductor pollicis brevis activity - a key early sign in carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: Which nerve is injured in a fracture neck of fibula:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The common peroneal nerve is highly susceptible to injury at the fibular neck due to its superficial course.

  • It winds laterally around the neck of fibula after exiting the popliteal fossa.
  • The nerve is tethered and fixed as it pierces the peroneus longus, making it vulnerable to trauma or fracture at this site.
  • Injury leads to paralysis of the dorsiflexors and evertors of the foot → resulting in foot drop.
  • Sensory loss is seen over the anterolateral leg and dorsum of foot (via superficial peroneal nerve) and first web space (via deep peroneal nerve).
  • The patient typically exhibits a high-stepping gait to prevent dragging the toes.

Explanation of other options:

Superficial peroneal nerve (Option A): Branch of common peroneal; isolated injury causes sensory loss over the dorsum of foot, but foot drop does not occur.

Anterior tibial nerve (Option B): No such nerve; the anterior compartment is innervated by a deep peroneal nerve.

Deep peroneal nerve (Option D): Branch of common peroneal; injury causes isolated foot drop with sensory loss limited to first web space.

Key Takeaway:

Fracture at the fibular neck commonly injures the common peroneal nerve, leading to foot drop and sensory loss over the anterolateral leg and dorsum of the foot.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with an ulnar nerve injury is noted to have more prominent clawing in a distal (low) lesion compared to a proximal (high) lesion. What is this paradoxical phenomenon due to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ulnar paradox refers to the counterintuitive observation that clawing of the hand is more severe in distal (low) ulnar nerve palsy than in proximal (high) palsy.

  • In high ulnar nerve palsy, the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) is also paralysed.
  • Since FDP flexes the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) of the ring and little fingers, its paralysis reduces clawing.
  • In low palsy, FDP is spared, allowing active DIP flexion. This exaggerates the imbalance caused by unopposed long extensors and results in pronounced clawing.
  • Hence, the paradox is due to the preservation of FDP in low lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Flexor pollicis longus (Option B): Supplied by an anterior interosseous branch of median nerve; not involved in ulnar nerve pathology.

Extensor carpi radialis brevis (Option C): A radial nerve muscle; unrelated to the ulnar nerve or claw hand.

A simultaneous radial nerve disease (Option D): Not the cause of clawing or ulnar paradox.

Key Takeaway:

Ulnar paradox arises because FDP is spared in low ulnar palsy, worsening clawing; whereas in high lesions, FDP is paralyzed, lessening the deformity.

questions.text: Which of the following types of nerve injury characteristically results in the formation of a neuroma in continuity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Axonotmesis causes neuroma in continuity due to intact connective sheaths guiding regenerating axonal sprouts.

  • In axonotmesis, axonal continuity is lost, but endoneurium, perineurium, or epineurium remains partially or fully intact.
  • This allows axonal sprouts from the proximal segment to attempt regeneration.
  • If regeneration is disorganized, it leads to a neuroma in continuity-a fibrous swelling along the nerve with partial conduction.
  • A progressive Tinel's sign is often seen during regeneration, helping monitor the axonal regrowth
  • Sunderland Grade II-IV injuries correspond to axonotmesis.
  • Neurapraxia: Temporary conduction block without axonal disruption; no neuroma formation.(Option A ruled out)
  • Neurotmesis: Complete transection of both axon and sheaths; leads to terminal neuroma, not neuroma in continuity.(Option C ruled out)
  • Neuroma in continuity: Appears in axonotmesis and Sunderland grade III-IV injuries, where regeneration is misdirected or blocked despite partial sheath continuity.

Key Takeaway:

Neuroma in continuity is seen in axonotmesis, due to axonal regeneration through intact sheaths, often leading to incomplete or aberrant recovery.

questions.text: The Most commonly used tendon graft for tendon transfer is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Palmaris longus is most commonly used for tendon grafting due to its anatomical availability and minimal functional deficit upon harvest.

  • Palmaris longus is a slender tendon often absent in ~15% of individuals, but when present, it is superficial and easily accessible.
  • It plays a minor role in wrist flexion, so its removal causes minimal loss of function.
  • Commonly harvested in procedures involving flexor tendon grafting, especially when both FDS and FDP are damaged.
  • It is also used in staged tendon reconstruction surgeries where smooth tendon gliding is needed.
  • Other options like plantaris or toe extensors are also used but less commonly than palmaris longus.

Explanation of other options:

Semitendinosus (Option B): Used for ligament reconstructions (e.g., ACL), not preferred for upper limb tendon grafting.

Flexor Carpi Radialis (Option C): More functionally important; not preferred for graft harvesting.

Pronator Teres (Option D): Often used in tendon transfer (e.g., radial nerve palsy) but not for grafting.

Key Takeaway:

Palmaris longus is the tendon of choice for grafting due to accessibility and minimal donor morbidity.

choices.text: NCV is the best predictor of outcome within 48 hrs of injury
Positive Tinel's sign, if present, indicates the accurate location of injury
Traction nerve injuries are an indication for emergency surgery
In all cases of open wounds with clinical signs of nerve injury, nerve exploration must be done

questions.text: A True statement about nerve injury is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary nerve repair yields the best outcomes and is recommended in open injuries with clinical nerve involvement.

  • Nerve injuries with open wounds and clinical deficits must be explored early, as this allows primary repair-associated with better functional recovery.
  • Tinel's sign is a marker of regeneration, not the original injury site. It progresses distally with axonal recovery.
  • NCV (Nerve Conduction Velocity) is not reliable in the first 48 hours. Electromyography (EMG) may show denervation only after 2-3 weeks.
  • Traction injuries (especially low-energy ones) are typically neurapraxias—self-limiting and not an emergency indication for surgery.
  • In high-energy closed injuries or open wounds, early exploration is often warranted.
  • Failure of Tinel's sign to progress may indicate a more severe degree of injury (e.g., Sunderland Grade 4 or 5) and suggests the need for surgical intervention.
  • EMG studies help in long-term assessment but are not useful acutely.

Explanation of other options:

NCV (Option A): Not predictive in the first 48 hrs; axonal damage is not yet evident.

Tinel's sign (Option B): Indicates nerve regeneration zone, not the original site of injury.

Traction injuries (Option C): Commonly neurapraxias; not surgical emergencies unless associated with severe disruption.

Key Takeaway:

Open injuries with nerve signs must be explored early for optimal outcomes via primary nerve repair.

questions.text: The Best investigation to assess the prognosis of nerve injury is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nerve conduction studies (NCS) provide the most reliable objective data for prognosis in peripheral nerve injuries.

  • NCS is the investigation of choice to evaluate nerve continuity, conduction block, and axonal integrity.
  • It helps distinguish neurapraxia vs axonotmesis/neurotmesis and gives predictive information about recovery.
  • EMG becomes useful only after 10-21 days, detecting denervation potentials, but is less prognostic early on.
  • Tinel's sign is a clinical bedside marker of regeneration, not a prognostic investigation.
  • Evoked potentials are mainly used for CNS pathway assessments (e.g., somatosensory evoked potentials), not peripheral nerve prognosis.
  • NCS latency and amplitude guide recovery potential.
  • Combined use of EMG + NCS is ideal for localization, grading, and prognosis.
  • Early studies may be normal in neurapraxia; repeat testing helps track recovery.

Explanation of other options:

EMG (Option B): Helpful for detecting denervation but less useful in acute prognosis.

Tinel's sign (Option C): Clinical sign of axonal regeneration, not a formal investigation.

Evoked potentials (Option D): Used in CNS pathology; not standard in peripheral nerve injuries.

Key Takeaway:

Nerve conduction studies are the gold standard for evaluating prognosis in peripheral nerve injuries.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in crutch palsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Crutch palsy is a classic example of radial nerve neurapraxia caused by mechanical compression in the axilla.

  • The radial nerve runs in the spiral groove of the humerus and is vulnerable to compression in the axilla.
  • Crutch palsy results from prolonged pressure of axillary crutches pressing against the posterior cord.
  • This causes segmental demyelination (neurapraxia), without axonal disruption.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Wrist drop (due to paralysis of wrist extensors)
    • Sensory loss in the dorsum of the hand, especially over the first web space
  • As neurapraxia, complete recovery is expected within weeks (typically 6 weeks).
  • Treatment includes supportive care and cock-up splinting.

Explanation of other options:

Axillary nerve (Option A): Affects deltoid; injured in shoulder dislocation, not crutch use.

Brachial plexus (Option C): Would cause broader deficits; not typical in isolated crutch palsy.

Suprascapular nerve (Option D): Innervates supraspinatus and infraspinatus-unrelated to wrist drop.

Key Takeaway:

Radial nerve compression at the axilla due to crutch use causes neurapraxia with wrist drop and sensory loss.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a night of heavy drinking. He had fallen asleep on a barstool with his arm draped over the backrest. On waking up, he complains of wrist drop and numbness over the dorsum of the hand, especially the first web space. Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Compression of the radial nerve in the spiral groove during prolonged pressure (e.g., sleeping on a chair) leads to Saturday night palsy.

  • The radial nerve lies against the posterior humerus in the spiral groove and is vulnerable to external compression, especially during deep sleep or intoxication.
  • This leads to a neurapraxia (segmental demyelination) without axonal degeneration.
  • Classic signs:
    • Wrist drop due to loss of extensor muscle activity
    • Sensory loss over the dorsal first web space
  • Recovery is usually complete in 6-8 weeks with supportive care.
  • Management includes:
    • Cock-up splint
    • Physiotherapy
    • Observation unless symptoms persist

Explanation of other options:

Axillary nerve (Option A): Affects deltoid and teres minor; typically injured in shoulder dislocations.

Brachial plexus (Option C): Involves multiple roots and trunks-would result in widespread motor/sensory loss.

Suprascapular nerve (Option D): Supplies supraspinatus and infraspinatus; does not cause wrist drop.

Key Takeaway:

Saturday night palsy is a radial nerve neurapraxia due to external compression at the spiral groove; presents with wrist drop and resolves with conservative treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains a Sunderland type III Axillary nerve injury. What will his nerve injury be classified as, under Seddon's classification system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sunderland Type III injury, characterized by disruption of the axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium, falls under axonotmesis in Seddon's classification.

  • Seddon's classification divides nerve injuries into:
    • Neuropraxia: Temporary conduction block without axonal damage(Option A ruled out)
    • Axonotmesis: Axonal disruption with preserved connective tissue sheaths
    • Neurotmesis: Complete nerve transection including all sheaths(Option C ruled out)
  • Sunderland further subdivided injuries into five types:

Sunderland Type III injury = Axonotmesis (Seddon), and recovery depends on intact perineurium guiding axonal sprouts.

Key Takeaway:

Sunderland Type III injuries, involving axonal and endoneurial disruption, are categorized as axonotmesis under Seddon's system, with potential for partial regeneration.
